Accidental Release Prevention Policies
Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 The facility has developed a Risk Management Program to address the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements (40 CFR Part 68).  Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Berry Petroleum Cogeneration 18 staff is highly trained and utilize modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia for controlling NOx emissions. 

Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Injection System. Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18A?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 is located in Kern County, California, approximately 3.2 miles southwest pf Coty of Taft and 3.2 miles northwest of the City of Maricopa. The facility is adjacent to the State Route 33 Highway, approximately one mile west of Route #33. The site occupies 1.8 acres. The site is adjacent to the Berry Petroleum Company Production Facilities. The area around the facility is basically uninhabited. 

Berry Cogeneration-18 Facility owned by Berry Petroleum Company. Steam and electricity are produced and sold to the local power utility company. The Cogeneration facility began commercial operation in December 1986.  The facility consists of two Solar Mars 90 gas turbine generator sets for the production of electrical energy and two heat recovery steam generators (HRSG) for the production of thermal energy in the form of Steam. The cogeneration system electrica

l power output runs in parallel with the local utility company grid. Electrical power is consumed by surrounding Berry Production facilities supplying the electrical needs of the facilities up to 1000 Kilowatts.  Exhaust heat from the gas turbine is recovered in the heat recovery steam generation system. All steam produced is delivered to the Berry Petroleum Company for injection into the oil formation for enhanced oil recovery. 
The site is currently operated by Solar Assets Management Services and is manned 15 hrs a day and monitored 24 hrs a day. There are three personnel assigned to the facility - (1) Lead Technician and (2) Technician II personnel. 

The regulated substance managed at the Facility is anhydrous ammonia.  The maximum intended inventory is 94,050 lbs of anhydrous ammonia and it is stored in a pressurized horizontal storage tank at ambient temperature in liquid form.  When ambient conditions do not significantly promote the vaporization of liquid ammonia, a vaporizer is utilized to heat the liquid to its boiling point to produce vapor. The vapor ammonia is sent to a mixing chamber where it is mixed with air. The resulting vapor ammonia / air stream is then injected into the HRSG. This, in conjunction with the catalyst within the HRSG, allow for the reduction of NOx and other unwanted materials being sent to the environment. The exhaust gas containing a lower concentration of NOx is then sent from the HRSG to an exhaust stack. 

Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the EPA RMP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined and modeled for the ammonia injection system.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Two alternative release scenarios were modeled. The results can be found in the

Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab 2 of the CalARP/RMP Submittal Binder.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

A?Automatic/Manual Shutdown
A?Well designed Relief System.

The history of the Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 (i.e., no CalARP-applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Ammonia Injection System.

Accidental Release Prevention Program 
As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for the NOx abatement system.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facilityA?s maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia

is 94,050 lbs.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lbs threshold quantity for EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM.  The 500 lbs state threshold for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program is also exceeded.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:
A?Process Safety Information
A?Process Hazard Analysis
A?Operating Procedures
A?Training
A?Mechanical Integrity
A?Management of Change
A?Pre-Startup Safety Review
A?Compliance Audits
A?Incident Investigation
A?Employee Participation
A?Hot Work Permit
A?Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program
Neither Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 18 nor Solar Turbines are First Responders.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Berry Petroleum Cogeneration Facility 38 has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 A?3220 is in place.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the May 29th, 2009 PHA Report and June 2009 Seismic Assessment.  Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.
